title: County approves 2025-26 budget with no tax increase

content:

Yahoo is using AI to generate takeaways from this article. This means the info may not always match what's in the article. Reporting mistakes helps us improve the experience. Generate Key Takeaways

The Cumberland County Commission approved the county’s fiscal year 2025-26 budget without a property tax increase during a special-called meeting Tuesday evening.

The combined county and Cumberland County Board of Education budget is just under $177 million.

Total estimated revenues for the county’s general fund are projected to be $43,699,528, with total estimated expenditures of $43,865,056, for a negative $165,528. Those funds will come from the general fund, leaving an estimated ending fund balance of $28,503,176.

BOE estimated revenues are $76,351,314 with expenditures estimated at $78,782,281, leaving a deficit of $2,430,967, which will come from BOE’s fund balance. Ending fund balance is estimated to be $10,021,707.

The Cumberland County employee pay scale was raised to the recommended levels made from the study performed by Organizational Management Group. The raise was roughly a 12% increase over last year. Earlier this year in March, the county adopted a 6% increase. During the meeting this week, an additional 6% was approved at an estimated cost of $1.8 million. In the new scale, employees receive credit for their years of experience on the job and not by years of service.

Sheriff’s deputies, who are emergency medical response trained, will also earn an additional $2 per hour. The program will cost an estimated $30,000 per year.

Salary increases will be retroactive to July 1, the beginning of the fiscal year.

Some of the higher-cost capital projects included in the budget are:
• A new core infrastructure for the emergency communications system at an estimated cost of $785,064.
• A microwave hop for the emergency communications system at an estimated cost of $132,935.
• Three new ambulance remounts at an estimated cost of $420,000.
• Five new vehicles for the Sheriff’s Office at an estimated cost of $300,000.

A used backhoe and dump truck are also included for purchase for use in the solid waste/recycling department, community complex and road department. Several repairs at the county jail are also included in the capital projects. In all, capital purchases are estimated to be $2,817,630. Also included in that are roof replacements at three county buildings.

The nonprofit budget for contributions is $209,600. Organizations receiving contributions include the Chamber of Commerce, $52,500; Rescue Squad, $12,000; Fair Park Senior Center, $30,000; Hilltoppers, $17,100; Veterans Honor Guard, $4,500; Wags and Whiskers, $5,000; Fairfield Glade Fire Department, $37,500; Young Marines, $3,000; Avalon Center, $10,000; Court Appointed Special Advocates, $5,500; Cumberland County Playhouse, $20,000; Creative Compassion, $5,000; and Upper Cumberland Entrepreneurial Foundation, $7,500.

The first resolution was Fixing the Tax Levy in Cumberland County, Tennessee for the Fiscal Year beginning July 1. It was approved unanimously.

The second resolution was to approve and adopt an updated pay scale and classification schedule for county employees. It passed unanimously.

The third was was for making appropriations for the various funds, departments, institutions, offices and agencies of Cumberland County, TN, for the year beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2026. This resolution allocates funding to the various departments. It was approved 15-2 with commissioners Tom Isham, 2nd District; and Charles Seiber, 4th District, voting against.

The fourth resolution was for making appropriations to non-profit charitable organizations of Cumberland County, TN for the year beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2026. It was unanimously approved.

The fifth resolution was for the Election Commission and election officials’ compensation plan, updating the pay plan for election commission workers.

New rates include instruction/training, $25 per person, per class; early voting machine technicians, $140 per day, per election; Republican and Democrat machine technicians, $600 per month during months of election cycle 2026 and $250 per month retainer for months of no election cycle, 2025 and 2027. Absentee counting board will be paid $140 per day, per election; election day precinct officers will be paid $175 per day, per election; election day precinct judge/registrar will be paid $155 per day, per election; election commission members will receive $250 per month, which includes any special-called meetings and inservice training; election cycle extra helpers will be paid $120 per day; and nursing home registrars and jail registrars will be paid $120 per day.

The final resolution of the special-called meeting was for designating funds to the road department for a one-time contribution of $2.9 million for road repairs. The funds will come from American Rescue Plan Act funds. There will be no increase for the county’s maintenance of effort contribution to the road department in the future. The funds are for fiscal year 2025-26. The resolution was unanimously approved.

Deborah Holbrook, 8th District, did not attend the meeting.

The Cumberland County Commission will meet for its regular monthly meeting Monday, Aug. 18, at 6 p.m. at the Art Circle Public Library in the Cumberland Room.

The combined county and Cumbria Board of Education budget is just under $177 million. Total estimated revenues for the county’s general fund are projected to be $43,699,528, with total estimated expenditures of $43.865,056, leaving a deficit of $165,528. The county's employee pay scale was raised to recommended levels from a study by Organizational Management Group, marking a 12% increase over the previous year. Other notable capital projects included a new core infrastructure for the emergency communications system at an estimated cost of $785,064, and five new vehicles for the Sheriff’�s Office at a total of $300,000. The nonprofit budget for contributions is $209,600.
shortSummary: The Cumberland County Commission approved the fiscal year 2025-26 budget with no property tax increase, including significant employee pay increases and capital projects.
argos_summary: The Cumberland County Commission approved a budget for fiscal year 2025-26 totaling nearly $177 million without increasing property taxes. The budget includes a projected deficit for both the county and the Board of Education, with significant salary increases for county employees and additional funding for emergency services. Key capital projects include infrastructure improvements for emergency communications and new vehicles for the Sheriff’s Office, while contributions to local nonprofits total $209,600.
